p: The loss of biodiversity through extinction events has occurred since the beginning of life itself. The extinction of some organisms creates a crucial opportunity for the proliferation of other organisms that can exploit the changing environment. Biologists study this phenomenon and are particularly interested in the consequences of a relatively new extinction driver, that is, human activity during what is described as the Anthropocene epoch [ 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]. One unique facet of extinction during the Anthropocene is that biodiversity loss via extinction occurs without biodiversity replacement [ 6]. This may be partly due to the conversion of highly biodiverse localities into managed systems required to produce the crops and livestock needed to sustain the growing human population [ 7].
